DISCLAIMER
   The Codified Ordinances and other documents that appear in this FOLIO Infobase
may not reflect the most current legislation adopted by the Municipality. The
Codified Ordinances are provided for informational purposes only and should not be
relied upon as the definitive authority for local legislation. Additionally, the
formatting and pagination of the posted documents vary from the formatting and
pagination of the official copy. The official printed copy of the Codified
Ordinances should be consulted prior to any action being taken.
   For further information regarding the official version of any portion of the
Codified Ordinances in this FOLIO Infobase, please contact the Municipality
directly.
CERTIFICATION
   We, Ray Lewis, Mayor, and Stephanie Smith, Fiscal Officer of McDonald, Ohio,
pursuant to Ohio Revised Code 731.23 and 731.42, hereby certify that the
general and permanent ordinances of the Village of McDonald, Ohio, as revised,
rearranged, compiled, renumbered as to sections, codified and printed herewith
in component codes are correctly set forth and constitute the Codified
Ordinances of McDonald, Ohio, 1985, as amended to August 20, 2025.

ADOPTING ORDINANCE NO. 2421-86
AN ORDINANCE TO APPROVE, ADOPT AND ENACT THE CODIFIED ORDINANCES; TO REPEAL
ORDINANCES IN CONFLICT THEREWITH; TO PUBLISH THE ENACTMENT OF NEW MATTER; AND
DECLARING AN EMERGENCY.
 
   WHEREAS, the Council of the Village of McDonald, Ohio, has had the matter of
codification and general revision of the ordinances before it for some time,
and
 
   WHEREAS, it has heretofore entered into a contract with the Walter H. Drane
Company to prepare and publish such codification, and
 
   WHEREAS, the codification of such ordinances, together with the new matter
to be adopted, the matters to be amended and those to be repealed are before
the Council.
 
   BE IT ORDAINED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE VILLAGE OF McDONALD, TRUMBULL COUNTY,
STATE OF OHIO:
 
SECTION I. That the ordinances of the Village of McDonald, Ohio, of a general
and permanent nature, as revised, codified, rearranged and consolidated into
component codes, titles, chapters and sections are hereby approved, adopted and
enacted as the Codified Ordinances of the Village of McDonald, Ohio, 1985.
   One book-form copy of the Codified Ordinances shall be certified as correct
by the Mayor and the Clerk, attached to this Ordinance as a part hereof, and
filed with the permanent records of the Village of McDonald, Ohio.
 
SECTION II. That the provisions of this Ordinance, including all provisions of
the Codified Ordinances, shall be in full force and effect as provided in
Section 5 of this Ordinance. All ordinances and resolutions or parts thereof
enacted prior to which are inconsistent with any provision of the Codified
Ordinances, are hereby repealed as of the effective date of this Ordinance
except as follows:
   (a)    The enactment of the Codified Ordinances shall not be construed to
affect a right or liability accrued or incurred under any legislative
provisions prior to the effective date of such enactment, or any action or
proceeding for the enforcement of such right or liability. Such enactment shall
not be construed to relieve any person from punishment for an act committed in
the violation of any such legislative provisions, nor to affect an indictment
or prosecution therefor.
For such purposes, any such legislative provision shall continue in full force
notwithstanding its repeal for the purpose of revision and codification.
   (b)    The repeal provided above shall not affect:
      (1)    The grant or creation of a franchise, license, right, easement or
privilege.
      (2)   The purchase, sale, lease or transfer of property.
      (3)   The appropriation or expenditure of money or promise or guarantee
of payment.
      (4)    The assumption of any contract or obligation.
      (5)   The issuance and delivery of any bonds, obligations or other
instruments of indebtedness.
      (6)    The levy or imposition of taxes, assessments or charges.
      (7)    The establishment, naming, vacating or grade level of any street
or public way.
      (8)   The dedication of property or plat approval.
      (9)    The annexation or detachment of territory.
      (10)    Any legislation enacted subsequent to September 30, 1985.
SECTION III. That all legislation enacted subsequent to September 30, 1985,
which amended, replaced or otherwise affected a material provision of those
ordinances existing prior to September 30, 1985 shall be deemed to amend,
replace or affect the analogous or comparable section of the Codified
Ordinances as reflected in the Comparative Section Table of the same, or as
otherwise indicated by the content or purpose of such subsequent legislation.
SECTION IV. That this Ordinance is hereby declared to be an emergency measure
necessary the immediate preservation of the public peace, health, safety and
welfare of the residents of the Village, the reason for the necessity being
that there exists an imperative need for the publication and distribution of
the Codified Ordinances to the officials and residents of the Village, so as to
facilitate administration and daily operation and avoid practical and legal
entanglements.
SECTION V. That this Ordinance shall become effective at the earliest date
allowed by law.
   Passed in Council this  1st              day of  April , 1986.
Robert W. Zajack
Mayor
Attest:
Joseph R. McHale
Clerk

EDITOR'S NOTE
     The arrangement and numbering of the Codified Ordinances into component
codes, titles, chapters and sections are based on an adaptation of the decimal
numbering system which is similar to that used in the Ohio Revised Code, and in
accord with the best accepted practice in instituting a codification. Each
section is self-identifying as to code, chapter and section number. For
example, 305.06 indicates that the code number is 3, the chapter number is 305
(or the 5th chapter within code 3), and the section number is .06. The code and
chapter numbers appear left of the decimal, with the code number preceding the
first two digits left of the decimal, and the chapter number being all digits
left of the decimal. The section number appears right of the decimal. As
another example, 113.10 indicates the code number is 1, the chapter number is
113 (or the 13th chapter within code 1), and the section number is .10.
     This numbering system has the advantage of inherent flexibility in
allowing for an almost endless amount of expansion. Codes, titles and chapters
initially are odd-numbered, thus reserving the use of even numbers for future
legislation. Sections within chapters are consecutively numbered, except that
penalty provisions are usually assigned the number .99 as used in the Revised
Code. Newly created sections subsequent to the original codification may be
indicated by three digits right of the decimal in the event the law properly
belongs between two consecutively numbered sections. For example, newly created
575.061, 575.062 and 575.063 follow 575.06 and precede 575.07 to be placed in
their logical position.
     Section histories enable a user to trace the origin of the law contained
in the section. The history indicates the derivation by reference to either its
passage date and the ordinance number originally assigned to it at that time,
or to its inclusion in any prior code. Sections without histories indicate that
the section contains new matter which was ordained by the Adopting Ordinance
which enacts the Codified Ordinances.
     The Comparative Section Table is included to show the disposition of every
ordinance included in the Codified Ordinances. It indicates whether a given
ordinance was consolidated with another into one section or split into two or
more sections. Cross references direct the user to subject matter reasonably
related to material contained within a given chapter.

501.04
 
 
101.01 DESIGNATION; CITATION; HEADINGS.
   (a)   All ordinances of a permanent and general nature of the Municipality
as revised, codified, rearranged, renumbered and consolidated into component
codes, titles, chapters and sections shall be known and designated as the
Codified Ordinances of McDonald, Ohio, 1985, for which designation "Codified
Ordinances" may be substituted. Code, title, chapter and section headings do
not constitute any part of the law as contained in the Codified Ordinances.
(ORC 1.01)
   (b)   All references to codes, titles, chapters and sections are to such
components of the Codified Ordinances unless otherwise specified. Any component
code may be referred to and cited by its name, such as the "Traffic Code".
Sections may be referred to and cited by the designation "Section" followed by
the number, such as "Section
101.01".
      
101.02 GENERAL DEFINITIONS.
   As used in the Codified Ordinances, unless another definition is provided or
the context otherwise requires:
   (a)   "And" may be read "or", and "or" may be read "and", if the sense
requires it.
      (ORC 1.02(F))
   (b)   "Another" when used to designate the owner of property which is the
subject of an offense, includes not only natural persons but also every other
owner of property.
      (ORC 1.02(B))
   (c)   "Bond" includes an undertaking and "undertaking" includes a bond.
      (ORC 1.02(D), (E))
   (d)   "Council" means the legislative authority of the Municipality.
   (e)   "County" means Trumbull County, Ohio.
   (f)(1)   “Internet” means the international computer network of both federal
and nonfederal interoperable packet switched data networks, including the
graphical subnetwork known as the world wide web. (ORC 1.59(K))
   (f)   "Keeper" or "proprietor" includes all persons, whether acting by
themselves or as a servant, agent or employee.
   (g)   "Land" or "real estate" includes rights and easements of an
incorporeal nature.
      (ORC 701.01(F))
   (h)   "Municipality" or “Village” means the Village of McDonald, Ohio.
   (i)   "Oath" includes affirmation and "swear" includes affirm.
      (ORC 1.59(B))
   (j)   "Owner", when applied to property, includes any part owner, joint
owner or tenant in common of the whole or part of such property.
   (k)   "Person" includes an individual, corporation, business trust, estate,
trust, partnership and association.
      (ORC 1.59(C))
   (l)   "Premises", as applied to property, includes land and buildings.
   (m)   "Property" means real and personal property.
      (ORC 1.59(E))
      "Personal property" includes all property except real.
      "Real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments.
   (n)   "Public authority" includes boards of education; the Municipal,
County, State or Federal government, its officers or an agency thereof; or any
duly authorized public official.
   (o)   "Public place" includes any street, sidewalk, park, cemetery, school
yard, body of water or watercourse, public conveyance, or any other place for
the sale of merchandise, public accommodation or amusement.
   (p)   "Registered mail" includes certified mail and "certified mail"
includes registered mail.
      (ORC 1.02(G))
   (q)   "Rule" includes regulation. (ORC 1.59(F))
   (r)   "Sidewalk" means that portion of the street between the curb line and
the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians.
   (s)   "This State" or "the State" means the State of Ohio.
      (ORC 1.59(G))
   (t)   "Street" includes alleys, avenues, boulevards, lanes, roads, highways,
viaducts and all other public thoroughfares within the Municipality.
   (u)   "Tenant" or "occupant", as applied to premises, includes any person
holding a written or oral lease, or who actually occupies the whole or any part
of such premises, alone or with others.
   (v)   "Whoever" includes all persons, natural and artificial; partners;
principals, agents and employees; and all officials, public or private.
      (ORC 1.02(A))
   (w)   "Written" or "in writing" includes any representation of words,
letters, symbols or figures. This provision does not affect any law relating to
signatures.
      (ORC 1.59(J))
101.03 RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
   (a)   Common and Technical Usage. Words and phrases shall be read in context
and construed according to the rules of grammar and common usage. Words and
phrases that have acquired a technical or particular meaning, whether by
legislative definition or otherwise, shall be construed accordingly.
(ORC 1.42)
   (b)   Singular and Plural; Gender; Tense. As used in the Codified
Ordinances, unless the context otherwise requires:
      (1)   The singular includes the plural, and the plural includes the
singular.
      (2)   Words of one gender include the other genders.
      (3)   Words in the present tense include the future.
         (ORC 1.43)
   (c)   Calendar; Computation of Time.
      (1)   Definitions.
         A.   "Week" means seven consecutive days.
         B.   "Year" means twelve consecutive months.
            (ORC 1.44)
      (2)   If a number of months is to be computed by counting the months from
a particular day, the period ends on the same numerical day in the concluding
month as the day of the month from which the computation is begun, unless there
are not that many days in the concluding month, in which case the period ends
on the last day of that month.
         (ORC 1.45)
      (3)   A.   The time within which an act is required by law to be done
shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day; except
that when the last day falls on Sunday or a legal holiday, then the act may be
done on the next succeeding day that is not a Sunday or a legal holiday.
         B.   When a public office, in which an act required by law is to be
performed, is closed to the public for the entire day that constitutes the last
day for doing the act or before its usual closing time on that day, the act may
be performed on the next succeeding day that is not a Sunday or a legal
holiday.
         C.   As used in subsections (c)(1) and (c)(2) of this section, legal
holiday means the following days:
            1.   The first day of January, known as New Year’s Day;
            2.   The third Monday in January, known as Martin Luther King, Jr.
Day;
            3.   The third Monday in February, known as Washington-Lincoln Day;
            4.   The day designated in the “Act of June 28, 1968”, 82 Stat.
250, 5 U.S.C. § 6103, as amended, for the commemoration of Memorial Day;
            5.   The nineteenth day of June, known as Juneteenth day;
            6.   The fourth day of July, known as Independence Day;
            7.   The first Monday in September, known as Labor Day;
            8.   The second Monday in October, known as Columbus Day;
            9.   The eleventh day of November, known as Veteran’s Day;
            10.   The fourth Thursday in November, known as Thanksgiving Day;
            11.   The twenty-fifth day of December, known as Christmas Day; and
            12.   Any day appointed and recommended by the Governor of this
state or the President of the United States as a holiday.
         D.   If any day designated in this section as a legal holiday falls on
a Sunday, the next succeeding day is a legal holiday.
            (ORC 1.14)
      (4)   When legislation is to take effect or become operative from and
after a day named, no part of that day shall be included.
         (ORC 1.15)
      (5)   In all cases where the law shall require any act to be done in a
reasonable time or reasonable notice to be given, such reasonable time or
notice shall mean such time only as may be necessary for the prompt performance
of such duty or compliance with such notice.
   (d)   Authority. When the law requires an act to be done which may by law as
well be done by an agent as by the principal, such requirement shall be
construed to include all such acts when done by an authorized agent.
   (e)   Joint Authority. All words purporting to give joint authority to three
or more municipal officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such
authority to a majority of such officers or other persons, unless it shall be
otherwise expressly declared in the law giving the authority or inconsistent
with State statute or Charter provisions.
   (f)   Exceptions. The rules of construction shall not apply to any law which
shall contain any express provision excluding such construction, or when the
subject matter or context of such law may be repugnant thereto.
101.04 REVIVOR; EFFECT OF AMENDMENT OR REPEAL.
   (a)   The repeal of a repealing ordinance does not revive the ordinance
originally repealed nor impair the effect of any saving clause therein.
(ORC 1.57)
   (b)   An ordinance which is re-enacted or amended is intended to be a
continuation of the prior ordinance and not a new enactment, so far as it is
the same as the prior ordinance.
(ORC 1.54)
   (c)   The re-enactment, amendment or repeal of an ordinance does not, except
as provided in subsection (d) hereof:
      (1)   Affect the prior operation of the ordinance or any prior action
taken thereunder;
      (2)   Affect any validation, cure, right, privilege, obligation or
liability previously acquired, accrued, accorded or incurred thereunder;
      (3)   Affect any violation thereof or penalty, forfeiture or punishment
incurred in respect thereto, prior to the amendment or repeal;
      (4)   Affect any investigation, proceeding or remedy in respect of any
such privilege, obligation, liability, penalty, forfeiture or punishment; and
the investigation, proceeding or remedy may be instituted, continued or
enforced, and the penalty, forfeiture or punishment imposed, as if the
ordinance had not been repealed or amended.
   (d)   If the penalty, forfeiture or punishment for any offense is reduced by
a re-enactment or amendment of an ordinance, the penalty, forfeiture, or
punishment, if not already imposed, shall be imposed according to the ordinance
as amended.
(ORC 1.58)
101.05 CONSTRUCTION OF SECTION REFERENCES.
   (a)   A reference to any portion of the Codified Ordinances applies to all
re-enactments or amendments thereof.
(ORC 1.55)
   (b)   If a section refers to a series of numbers or letters, the first and
the last numbers or letters are included.
(ORC 1.56)
   (c)   Wherever in a penalty section reference is made to a violation of a
series of sections or of subsections of a section, such reference shall be
construed to mean a violation of any section or subsection included in such
reference.
   References in the Codified Ordinances to action taken or authorized under
designated sections of the Codified Ordinances include, in every case, action
taken or authorized under the applicable legislative provision which is
superseded by the Codified Ordinances.
(ORC 1.23)
101.06 CONFLICTING PROVISIONS.
   (a)   If there is a conflict between figures and words in expressing a
number, the words govern.
(ORC 1.46)
   (b)   If a general provision conflicts with a special or local provision,
they shall be construed, if possible, so that effect is given to both. If the
conflict between the provisions is irreconcilable, the special or local
provision prevails as an exception to the general provision, unless the general
provision is the later adoption and the manifest intent is that the general
provision prevail.
(ORC 1.51)
   (c)   (1)   If ordinances enacted at different meetings of Council are
irreconcilable, the ordinance latest in date of enactment prevails.
      (2)   If amendments to the same ordinance are enacted at different
meetings of Council, one amendment without reference to another, the amendments
are to be harmonized, if possible, so that effect may be given to each. If the
amendments are substantively irreconcilable, the latest in date of enactment
prevails. The fact that a later amendment restates language deleted by an
earlier amendment, or fails to include language inserted by an earlier
amendment, does not of itself make the amendments irreconcilable. Amendments
are irreconcilable only when changes made by each cannot reasonably be put into
simultaneous operation.
         (ORC 1.52)
101.07 DETERMINATION OF LEGISLATIVE INTENT.
   (a)   In enacting an ordinance, it is presumed that:
      (1)   Compliance with the constitutions of the State and of the United
States is intended;
      (2)   The entire ordinance is intended to be effective;
      (3)   A just and reasonable result is intended;
      (4)   A result feasible of execution is intended.
         (ORC 1.47)
   (b)   An ordinance is presumed to be prospective in its operation unless
expressly made retrospective.
(ORC 1.48)
   (c)   If an ordinance is ambiguous, the court, in determining the intention
of Council may consider among other matters:
      (1)   The object sought to be attained;
      (2)   The circumstances under which the ordinance was enacted;
      (3)   The legislative history;
      (4)   The common law or former legislative provisions, including laws
upon the same or similar subjects;
      (5)   The consequences of a particular construction;
      (6)   The administrative construction of the ordinance.
         (ORC 1.49)
101.08 SEVERABILITY.
   If any provision of a section of the Codified Ordinances or the application
thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity does not
affect the other provisions or applications of the section or related sections
which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to
this end the provisions are severable.
(ORC 1.50)
101.99 GENERAL PENALTY.
   Whenever, in the Codified Ordinances or in any ordinance of the
Municipality, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an
offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever the doing of any act is required or the
failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is
otherwise provided, whoever violates any such provision shall be punished by a
fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00). A separate offense shall be
deemed committed each day during or on which a violation continues or occurs.
CHAPTER 103
Official Standards
   EDITOR'S NOTE: There are no sections in Chapter
103. This chapter been established to provide a place for cross references and
any future legislation.

CHAPTER 105
Open Meetings
105.01   Definitions.
105.02   Notice of regular and organizational meetings.
105.03   Notice of special meetings.
105.04   Notice to news media of special meetings.
105.05   Notification of discussion of specific types of public business.
105.06   Determination of meetings; notification attempts.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Open meetings - see Ohio R. C. 121.22
Council meetings - see ADM.
121.01,
121.02
 
 
105.01 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    As used in this chapter:
      (1)    "Clerk" means the Clerk of Council of the Village of McDonald.
      (2)    "Day" means calendar day.
      (3)    "Meeting" means any prearranged discussion of the public business
of the Municipal Body by a majority of the members of the Municipal Body.
      (4)    "Municipal Body" means each of the following:
         Council
         Planning Commission
         Board of Zoning Appeals
         Treasury Investment Board
and committees of the above Municipal Bodies comprised of members of such
Bodies if such committees are comprised of a majority of the members of the
Village Council, or are decision-making committees.
      (5)    "Oral notification" means notification given orally either in
person or by telephone, directly to the person for whom such notification is
intended, or by leaving an oral message for such person at the address, or if
by telephone at the telephone number, of such person as shown on the records
kept by the Clerk under this chapter.
      (6)    "Post" means to post in an area accessible to the public during
the usual business hours at the office of the Clerk and at the following
locations:
         A.    The United States Post Office
         B.    The Municipal Building
         C.    The corner of Grant Street and Fourth Street
         D.    The corner of Pennsylvania Avenue and Fifth Street
         E.    The corner of Illinois Avenue and Fourth Street
A notice identifying the locations at which notifications will be posted
pursuant to this chapter shall be published by the Clerk within ten calendar
days after the adoption of these regulations.
      (7)    "Published" means published once in a newspaper having a general
circulation in the municipality, as defined in Ohio R. C. 7.12, except that no
portion of such newspaper need be printed in the Municipality.
      (8)    "Special meeting” means a meeting which is neither a regular
meeting nor an adjournment of a regular, or special, meeting to another time or
day to consider items specifically stated on the original agenda of such
regular or special meeting.
      (9)    "Written notification" means notification in writing mailed,
telegraphed or delivered to the address of the person for whom such
notification is tended as shown on the records kept by the Clerk under these
Rules, or in any way delivered to such person. If mailed, such notification
shall be mailed by first-class mail, deposited in a U.S. Postal Service mailbox
no later than the second day preceding the day of the meeting to which such
notification refers, provided that at least one regular mail delivery day falls
between the day of mailing and the day of such meeting.
         (Ord. 2082-75. Passed 12-2-75; Adopting Ordinance.)
105.02 NOTICE OF REGULAR AND ORGANIZATIONAL MEETINGS.
   (a)    The Clerk shall post a statement of the time and place of regular
meetings of each Municipal Body for each calendar year not later than the
second day preceding the day of the first regular meeting (other than the
organizational meeting) of the calendar year of that Municipal Body. The Clerk
shall check at reasonable intervals to ensure that such statement remains so
posted during such calendar year. If at any time during the calendar year the
time or place of regular meetings, or of any regular meeting, is changed on a
permanent or temporary basis, a statement of the time and place of such changed
regular meetings shall be so posted by the Clerk at least twenty-four hours
before the time of the first changed regular meeting.
   (b)    The Clerk shall post a statement of the time and place of any
organizational meeting of a Municipal Body at least twenty-four hours before
the time of such organizational meeting.
   (c)    Upon the adjournment of any regular or special meeting to another
day, the Clerk shall promptly post notice of the time and place of such
adjourned meeting.
(Ord. 2082-75. Passed 12-2-75.)
105.03 NOTICE OF SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   (a)    Except in the case of a special meeting referred to in Section
105.04(d), the Clerk shall, no later than a minimum of twelve hours before the
time of a special meeting of a Municipal Body, post a statement of the time,
place and purposes of such special meeting.
   (b)   The statement under this section and the notifications under Section
105.04 shall state such specific or general purpose or purposes then known to
the Clerk to be intended to be considered at such special meeting and may
state, as an additional general purpose, that any other business as may
properly come before such Municipal Body at such meeting may be considered and
acted upon.
(Ord. 2082-75. Passed 12-2-75.)
105.04 NOTICE TO NEWS MEDIA OF SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   (a)   Any news medium organization that desires to be given advance
notification of special meetings of a Municipal Body shall file with the Clerk
a written request therefore and self-addressed stamped envelopes.
   Except in the event of an emergency requiring immediate official action as
referred to in subsection (d) hereof, a special meeting shall not be held
unless at least twenty- four hours advance notice of the time, place and
purposes of such special meeting is given to the news media that have requested
such advance notification in accordance with subsection (b) hereof.
   (b)    News media requests for such advance notification of special meetings
shall specify: the Municipal Body that is the subject of such request; the name
of the medium; the name and address of the person to whom written notifications
to the medium may be mailed, telegraphed or delivered; (and) the names,
addresses and telephone numbers (including addresses and telephone numbers at
which notifications may be given either during or outside of business hours) of
at least two persons to either one of whom oral notifications to the medium may
be given.
   Any such request shall be effective for one year from the date of filing
with the Clerk or until the Clerk receives written notice from such medium
canceling or modifying such request, whichever is earlier. Each requesting news
medium shall be informed of such period of effectiveness at the time it files
its request. Such requests may be modified or extended only by filing a
complete new request with the Clerk. A request shall not be deemed to be made
unless it is complete in all respects, and such request may be conclusively
relied on by the Village, the Municipal Body that is the subject of such
request and the Clerk.
   (c)    The Clerk shall give such oral notification or written notification,
or both, as the Clerk determines, to the news media that have requested such
advance notification in accordance with subsection (b) hereof, of the time,
place and purposes of each special meeting, at least twenty-four hours prior to
the time of such special meeting.
   (d)    In the event of an emergency requiring immediate official action, a
special meeting may be held without giving twenty-four hours advance
notification thereof to the requesting news media. The persons calling such
meeting, or anyone or more of such persons or the Clerk on their behalf, shall
immediately give oral notification or written notification or both, as the
person or persons giving such notification determine, of the time, place and
purposes of such special meeting to such news media that have requested such
advance notification in accordance with subsection (b) hereof. The minutes or
the call, or both, of any such special meeting shall state the general nature
of the emergency requiring immediate official action. (Ord. 2082-75. Passed 12-
2-75.)
105.05 NOTIFICATION OF DISCUSSION OF SPECIFIC TYPES OF PUBLIC BUSINESS.
   (a)    Any person, upon written request and as provided herein, may obtain
reasonable advance notification of all meetings at which any specific type of
public business is scheduled to be discussed, provided that self-addressed,
stamped envelopes are delivered with the request.
   (b)    Such person may file a written request with the Clerk specifying: the
person's names, and the address(es) and telephone number(s) at or through which
the person can be reached during and outside of business hours; the specific
type of public business the discussion of which the person is requesting
advance notification; the Municipal Body that is the subject of such request;
and the number of calendar months (not to exceed twelve) which the request
covers. Such request may be modified or extended only by filing a complete new
request with the Clerk. A request shall not be deemed to be made unless it is
complete in all respects, and such request may be conclusively relied on by the
Village, Municipal Body that is the subject of such request, and the Clerk.
   (c)    The contents of written notification under this section may be a copy
of the agenda of the meeting. Written notification under this section may be
accomplished by giving advance written notification, by copies of the agenda of
all meetings of the Municipal Body that is the subject of such request.
(Ord. 2082-75. Passed 12-2-75.)
105.06 DETERMINATION OF MEETINGS; NOTIFICATION ATTEMPTS.
   (a)    Any person may visit or telephone the office of the Clerk during that
office's regular office hours to determine, based on information available at
that office: the time and place of regular meetings; the time, place and
purposes of any then known special meetings; and whether the available agenda
of any such future meeting states that any specific type of public business,
identified by such person, is to be discussed at such meeting.
   (b)    Any notification provided herein to be given by the Clerk may be
given by any person acting in behalf of or under the authority of the Clerk.
   (c)    A reasonable attempt at notification shall constitute notification in
compliance with this chapter. (Ord. 2082-75. Passed 12-2-75.)

121.01 REGULAR MEETINGS.
   Regular meetings of Council shall be held on the first and third Wednesday
of every month in the Council Chambers. Caucus shall start at 6:00 p.m. and the
meeting immediately following. (Ord. 3142-13. Passed 12-4-13.)
121.02 SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   Special meetings of Council shall be held at such time and place as ordered
by the Mayor or any three members of Council, as provided in Ohio R.C. 731.44
and 731.46.
(Ord. 870-62. Passed 3-20-62.)
121.03 NEW YEAR’S DAY MEETING.
   Council shall meet t the usual place for holding such meetings, at 12:00
noon on the January 1 after its election, at which time the newly-elected
Councilmen shall assume the duties of their office. In the event that this
meeting falls on a Sunday, Monday or Tuesday, then the regular Tuesday meeting
shall be dispensed with.
(Ord. 870-62. Passed 3-20-62.)
121.04 RULES OF COUNCIL.
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Pursuant to Ordinance 3142-13, passed December 4, 2013,
Council has adopted rules of Council procedure.
121.05 MUNICIPAL BUILDING ACCESS POLICY.
   The McDonald Municipal Building is for business use only. After normal
business hours access will be granted for the purpose of conducting official
business. Consideration may be given to extra ordinary events such as
Firefighters Homecoming festival, Fire Department Open House/Lions Club
Festival, Christmas Tree lighting ceremony etc.
(Ord. 3068-10. Passed 1-20-10.)

   (f)   If there is a newspaper of general circulation within the
Municipality, then legal publication may be placed in such newspaper.
(Ord. 2769-98. Passed 4-15-98.)

131.01 STENOGRAPHER/OFFICE MANAGER/CLERK OF COURT.
   (a)   The Village Stenographer/Office Manager/Clerk of Court shall be
appointed by the Mayor with approval of Council, and shall be under the
direction of the Mayor and Village Clerk, and shall perform all services
required of her in all departments to the end that the business of the
Municipality may be efficiently performed.
   (b)   The positions of Village Stenographer/Office Manager and Clerk of
Mayor’s Court be and are hereby combined into one position.
   (c)   The duties of the position of Village Stenographer/Office Manager/
Clerk of Court shall be those duties as provided for under existing ordinances
and such further duties as shall be designated by the Mayor and/or the Fiscal
Officer.
131.02 ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT.
   (a)   There is hereby established the position of Administrative Assistant
for the Village who shall be annually appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by
Council.
   (b)   The hourly wage for the Administrative Assistant, together with
holiday and vacation pay, hospitalization, life insurance and such other
employee benefits, shall be as provided by Council from time to time.
   (c)   The Administrative Assistant shall have flexible working hours and
shall have duties and responsibilities as follows:
      (1)   To assist the Office Manager and any and all administrators,
including but not limited to, the Mayor, Income Tax Administrator, Fiscal
Officer, and Village Administrator, for the Village of McDonald, Ohio;
      (2)   To collect or provide for the collection of all receivables for the
Village of McDonald, Ohio;
      (3)   To perform any and all administrative assignments, including but
not limited to, the preparation and mailing of all income tax forms and
statements, the collection and banking of monies generated by the same, the
preparation and mailing of all water bills, and the collection and banking of
monies generated by the same; and
      (4)   To assist with and perform any and all other duties and
responsibilities as assigned by the Office Manager.
   (d)   The Administrative Assistant shall be under the general supervision
and control of the Office Manager and shall have such other duties and
responsibilities as are prescribed by ordinance or by agreement and which are
not inconsistent herewith.
   (e)   The Administrative Assistant shall perform any and all duties and
shall perform all responsibilities as prescribed by the Mayor in addition to
those as set forth hereinabove.
(Ord. 2862-00. Passed 12-18-00.)
131.03 PUBLIC SAFETY AND SERVICE OFFICER.
   (a)   There is hereby established the position of Public Safety and Service
Officer for the Village.
   (b)   The Public Safety and Service Officer shall have and must have the
following certifications, training and qualifications:
      (1)   Certification, training and police commission at least equivalent
to that of a full-time police officer within the Village;
      (2)   License and/or State minimum requirements qualifying as Jailer;
      (3)   License and/or State minimum requirements qualifying as Dispatcher;
      (4)   Successfully pass and complete any and all in-house Village
training requirements;
      (5)   Successfully pass and complete an annual physical examination; and
      (6)   Establish and maintain residency within the Village.
   (c)    The Public Safety and Service Officer shall have and must have,
within one year after the original appointment, the following certifications,
training and qualifications:
      (1)    Certifications, training and qualifications for a full-time
firefighter and an emergency medical technician (EMT) as required by the Ohio
Revised Code and State law.
   (d)    The Public Safety and Service Officer shall be paid as provided by
Council from time to time. The Public Safety and Service Officer shall have
benefits of holidays and vacation pay, hospitalization, life insurance and such
other employee benefits as provided to all full-time hourly wage employees for
the Village.
   (e)    The Public Safety and Service Officer shall have scheduled working
hours and shall have, and shall successfully perform, the duties and
responsibilities as follows:
      (1)    Assist and work in conjunction with the Police Department and Fire
Department and to further work under the direct supervision of the Police Chief
on a daily basis;
      (2)    Assist with the normal duties required of a full-time police
officer;
      (3)    Assist with the Fire Department and perform specialized duties and
responsibilities at the direction of the Fire Chief;
      (4)    Schedule the Dispatchers, assist the Dispatchers, and assist with
the training and continued education regarding Dispatchers;
      (5)    Establish, maintain and supervise in-house training for the Police
Department and Fire Department;
      (6)    Maintain, repair and operate the fire trucks, fire equipment and
other related equipment for the benefit of the Fire Department;
      (7)    Assist with emergency medical calls;
      (8)    Establish, maintain and supervise educational programs for
juveniles and/or students at both the High School and Elementary School in
conjunction with school officials; and
      (9)    Assist the Police Chief on specific investigations and other
matters related to court proceedings.
   (f)    The Public Safety and Service Officer shall be under the general
supervision and control of the Mayor and the Mayor may delegate this
supervision and control to the Police Chief and/or Fire Chief, on a daily
basis, whenever the Mayor deems it appropriate. The Public Safety and Service
Officer shall have such other duties and responsibilities as are prescribed by
ordinance or by directive from the Mayor and which are not inconsistent
herewith.
   (g)    The Public Safety and Service Officer shall perform all duties and
shall perform all responsibilities as prescribed by the Mayor in addition to
those as set forth hereinabove.
(Ord. 2587-91. Passed 10-2-91.)
CHAPTER 133
Fiscal Officer
133.01    Established; duties.
133.02   Investment policy.
133.03   Dishonored check fee.
133.04   Unclaimed Money Agency Fund.
133.05   Blanket purchase orders.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Auditing accounts - see Ohio R.C. 733.12 et seq.
Election and term - see Ohio R.C. 733.26
Powers and duties - see Ohio R.C. 733.27
Merger of certain offices - see Ohio R.C. 733.28
 
 
 
133.01 ESTABLISHED; DUTIES.
   (a)   In accordance with Ohio R.C. 733.26(B), and due to the vacancy in the
position of the Village Clerk, there is hereby created the appointed position
of a full-time Village Fiscal Officer. The salary of the Village Fiscal Officer
shall be as provided by Council.
   (b)   All aspects pertaining to the appointment, removal, and duties of
Village Fiscal Officer are set forth in accordance with Ohio R.C. 733.262. The
Village Fiscal Officer shall have those powers, duties, and functions as
provided by the general laws of the State of Ohio.
(Ord. 3138-13. Passed 8-21-13.)
133.02 INVESTMENT POLICY.
   (a)   Council approves and adopts the written investment policy attached to
Ordinance 3172-15 and incorporated therein as Exhibit A.
   (b)   All investments shall comply with the written investment policy, as
well as Ohio R.C. 731.56 to 731.59, and 135.14.
   (c)   Council further directs the Fiscal Officer to file with the Auditor of
the State of Ohio a copy of the written investment policy.
(Ord. 3172-15. Passed 5-6-15.)
133.03 DISHONORED CHECK FEE.
   To cover the administrative expense and various other costs involved,
directly or indirectly, with these dishonored negotiable instruments, each and
every individual, partnership, corporation, joint venture, limited liability
company, trusts, and/or other entity shall be charged, assessed, and/or levied
thirty dollars ($30.00) for each and every dishonored negotiable instrument
made payable to the Village or any subdivision thereof or any agents,
representatives, assigns, principals, or officers of the Village.
(Ord. 2924-02. Passed 12-4-02.)
 
133.04 UNCLAIMED MONEY AGENCY FUND.
   (a)   The Village Fiscal Officer is hereby authorized and directed to create
and establish a restricted fund for unclaimed money known as the “Unclaimed
Money Agency Fund.” The purpose of this Fund shall be receiving, accounting
for, and disbursing unclaimed money.
   (b)   Unclaimed money includes without limitation checks issued by the
Village that are not negotiated for a period of at least one hundred eighty
(180) days after the issuance and money deposited with the Village in
accordance with the ordinances or other requirements of the Village no longer
subject to being used by the Village for the purpose for which it was
deposited.
   (c)   All such unclaimed money not otherwise paid out shall be deposited in
the Unclaimed Money Agency Fund where said money shall be retained until
claimed by the lawful owner. If the money is not claimed by the lawful owner
within a period of five (5) years from the date it is deposited in the
Unclaimed Money Agency Fund, the money shall revert to the General Fund of the
Village.
   (d)   The Village Fiscal Officer is further authorized and directed to make
application to the Auditor of the State’s Office, Local Governmental Services
Division, for the approval of the creation of the “Unclaimed Money Agency
Fund,” pursuant to the provisions of Sections 5705.09 and/or 5705.12 of the
Ohio Revised Code.
(Ord. 3140-13. Passed 11-6-13.)
133.05 BLANKET PURCHASE ORDERS.
   (a)   There are hereby established monetary limits for blank purchase orders
as follows:                        
      (1)   Utilities - fifty thousand and 00/100 dollars ($50,000.00)
      (2)   Materials and supplies - twenty thousand and 00/100 dollars
($20,000.00)
      (3)   Contractual services - ninety-five thousand and 00/100 dollars
($95,000.00)
      (4)   Debt service - fifty thousand and 00/100 dollars ($50,000.00)
   (b)   The Fiscal Officer is authorized to establish and adopt policies and
procedures for issuance of blanket purchase orders by the Village, subject to
the monetary limits set forth herein and the Ohio Revised Code. Only one
blanket purchase order may be outstanding at one particular time for any one
particular line item appropriation.
(Ord. 3252-20. Passed 8-19-20.)
 
CHAPTER 137
Solicitor
137.01   Term of office.
137.02   Qualifications and duties.
137.03   Police Prosecutor.
137.04   Necessary expenses; extraordinary services.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Legal counsel - see Ohio R.C. 733.48
Preparation of bonds - see Ohio R.C. 733.70
 
 
137.01 TERM OF OFFICE.
   Legal counsel shall be provided for the Municipality and the person employed
as such shall be known as the Solicitor. He shall be appointed by Council.
137.02 QUALIFICATIONS AND DUTIES.
   It shall be the duty of the Solicitor to act as attorney and counsel for the
Village and the officers thereof, in their respective capacity, and as such
attorney, to prosecute and defend all actions for or against the Village or any
department or officer thereof, in their respective capacity aforesaid, and to
attend all regular and special Council meetings, Planning Commission meetings
and meetings of the Board of Zoning Appeals during the term of his employment,
except as otherwise determined by Council, and to render legal opinions to
Council and to any department or officer of the Village upon request in
writing.
(Ord. 2458-87. Passed 5-19-87.)
137.03 POLICE PROSECUTOR.
   (a)   In addition to the duties in Section
137.02, the Solicitor shall act as Police Prosecutor for the Village and
perform all such duties as provided for in subsection (b) hereof for which he
shall receive the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per month from the
General Fund. (Ord. 2458-87. Passed 5-19-87.)
   (b)   The duties of the Prosecutor shall be as follows:
      (1)   To prosecute violations of Village ordinances and State statutes on
behalf of the Village before the Mayor’s Court.
      (2)   To render legal opinions on matters of law, regarding any matter
pending before the Mayor’s Court.
      (3)   To render legal opinions to the Police Department on matters of law
and, particularly, regarding the sufficiency of evidence for arrests on
issuance of a warrant for the trials of any matter within the jurisdiction of
the Mayor’s Court. (Ord. 2109-76. Passed 6-1-76.)
137.04 NECESSARY EXPENSES; EXTRAORDINARY SERVICES.
   The Solicitor shall receive his necessary expenses while engaged in his
duties on behalf of the Village. In addition, the Solicitor shall receive the
reasonable hourly or per diem value of extraordinary services in connection
with capital improvements and court appearance, as suggested by the Trumbull
County Bar Association. (Ord. 2458-87. Passed 5-19-87.)
CHAPTER 138
Office Manager
138.01   Established; duties.
 
 
138.01 ESTABLISHED; DUTIES.
   (a)   The position of Office Manager is hereby created and established so
the residents of the Village may be served at all times in an efficient and
businesslike manner.
   (b)   The Office Manager shall be appointed by the Mayor with the approval
of Council, shall be under the direction of the Mayor, and shall have duties
and responsibilities as follows:
      (1)   To perform any and all office duties required fo her/him in all
departments and as the Mayor’s secretary, Clerk of Courts, and Secretary to the
Council; and
      (2)   Hire, schedule, and supervise the Secretary/receptionist(s) and the
Administrative Assistant with the approval of the Mayor and Council.
   (c)   The Office Manager shall be a full-time position and work forty (40)
hours per week and, in addition, shall attend all Council meetings and Court
sessions.
   (d)   The salary for the Office Manager is included in the current salary
Ordinance.
(Ord. 3221-18. Passed 8-15-18.)
CHAPTER 139
Police Department
   EDITOR’S NOTE: A “McDonald Police Manual of Practice, Procedure and
Deportment” was adopted by Ordinance 3113-12, passed March 21, 2012. Copies are
on file at the Village Hall.
139.01   Composition; appointment of members.
139.02   Captain.

139.05   Temporary promotions or transfers; employment of substitutes.

139.08   Compensation for extraordinary duties.

139.12   Canine unit standard operating procedures manual.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Composition - see Ohio R.C. 715.05, 737.16
General powers and duties - see Ohio R.C. 737.11, 737.18
Probationary period; final appointment - see Ohio R.C. 737.17
Removal and appeal - see Ohio R.C. 737.171
Police Pension and Disability Fund - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 742

161.10
 
 
139.01 COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS.
   The Police Department shall be composed of a Chief of Police, a Captain, a
Sergeant and such number of patrolmen and special policemen as may be
determined by Council from time to time.
   The Chief of Police, Captain, Sergeant and all members of the Police
Department shall be appointed by the Mayor with the advice and consent of
Council.
(Ord. 3314-25. Passed 3-20-25.)
139.02 CAPTAIN.
   (a)   There is hereby created the rank of Captain of Police who shall be
appointed by the Mayor with the approval of Council from the rank of regular
police officers of the Village of McDonald.
   (b)   The Captain of Police shall be in charge of the Police Department in
the absence of the Chief of Police. The Captain shall have the powers conferred
by law upon the Chief of Police, Captain of Police, and police officers in all
villages in the State. The Captain of Police shall have, in addition thereto,
the following duties and powers in the absence of the Chief of Police:
      (1)   To assign members of the Police Department their jobs and turns and
to any special detail required of them in emergencies;
      (2)   To summon to duty any member of the Police Department in case of
emergency of expediency;
      (3)   To keep a record of all activities of the Police Department as may
be ordered or prescribed by the Chief of Police, or by law required of him or
her, which occurs or transpires in the absence of the Chief of Police; and
      (4)   To make a report to the Chief of Police from time to time as may be
required of him or her.
         (Ord. 3314-25. Passed 3-20-25.)
139.03 RESIDENCY REQUIREMENT.
      Pursuant Ohio Revised Code 737.15, any legal requirement that the Chief
of Police be or become a resident of the Village of McDonald is waived.
(Ord. 3314-25. Passed 3-20-25.)
139.04 SPECIAL POLICEMEN.
   (a)   The Mayor shall appoint as many special policemen as he or she may
determine necessary for the maintenance of order in the Municipality.
   (b)   Special policemen shall have the powers conferred by law upon police
officers in municipalities of the State and such other powers not inconsistent
with the nature of their office as Council shall hereafter by ordinance confer.
(Ord. 3314-25. Passed 3-20-25.)
139.05 TEMPORARY PROMOTIONS OR TRANSFERS; EMPLOYMENT OF SUBSTITUTES.
   The Mayor may, if he or she believes it necessary, make temporary promotions
or transfers and employ substitutes. Substitutes so appointed shall receive the
pay of special policemen. (Ord. 3314-25. Passed 3-20-25.)
139.06 HOURS OF DUTY.
   All personnel of the Police Department shall, whenever feasible, work no
more than forty hours per week.
(Ord. 3314-25. Passed 3-20-25.)
139.07 SICKNESS OR ACCIDENT.
    The Mayor and the Chief of Police are hereby authorized to excuse from
duty, without deduction in pay, any regular member of the Police Department
because of sickness or accident contracted in the ordinary course of events or
for injury or sickness arising within the scope of his duty.
    However, the Mayor and the Chief of Police may require proof of such
sickness, accident or disability by physical examination on the part of any
physician whom they may choose; or the Mayor and the Chief of Police may accept
the certificate of a regular practicing physician. (Ord. 3314-25. Passed 3-20-
25.)
139.08 COMPENSATION FOR EXTRAORDINARY DUTIES.
   (a)    There is hereby provided the following schedule for compensation for
all full-time patrolmen and special patrolmen in the Police Department who are
required to attend hearings or trials as witnesses in any court in the area
and/or courts outside the limits of the Village of McDonald on their off-duty
hours:
   Compensation for off-duty time at any court in the area and/or courts
outside the limits of the Village of McDonald shall be at the regular hourly
rate for the employee(s) for a minimum of two hours.
   (b)    The Fiscal Officer is hereby authorized and directed to pay such
compensation monthly, or at any other reasonable timeframe to be determined by
the Fiscal Officer, upon receipt of signed time sheets with the authority of
and approval by the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 3314-25. Passed 3-20-25.)
139.09 TRUST FUNDS.
   (a)    Under the provisions of Ohio Revised Code 2923.35(d)(3) and 2933.43
(d)(4) and related sections of the Ohio Revised Code, there is hereby
established within the Special Revenue Fund of the Village, the Law Enforcement
Trust Fund.
   (b)    Under the provisions of Ohio Revised Code 2925.03(j) of the Ohio
Revised Code, there is hereby established within the Special Revenue Fund of
the Village, the Drug Law Enforcement Fund.
(Ord. 3314-25. Passed 3-20-25.)
139.10 JAIL ADMINISTRATOR AND SECURITY MANAGER.
   Intentionally omitted.
139.11 SERGEANT.
   (a)    There is hereby created the rank of Sergeant of police who shall be
appointed by the Mayor with the approval of Council from the rank of regular
police officers of the Village. The Sergeant shall serve a six month
probationary period.
   (b)    The Sergeant of police shall be in charge of the Police Department in
the absence of the Chief of Police and Captain. He or she shall have the powers
conferred by laws upon the Chief of Police, Police Captain, and police officers
in all Villages in the State. In the absence of the Chief of Police and the
Captains, the Sergeant shall be responsible for duties assigned to him or her
by the Chief of Police which include, but are not limited to:
      (1)   To assign members of the Police Department their jobs and any
special detail required of them in emergencies during their shifts.
      (2)   To be a first-line supervisor during his or her shift, directing
other members of the police department to their assigned tasks or duties, as
directed by the Chief of Police or Captain.
      (3)   To report to the Chief of Police or Captain of Police from time to
time, as may be required of him or her.
         (Ord. 3314-25. Passed 3-20-25.)
139.12 CANINE UNIT STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES MANUAL.
      The provisions of the Canine Unit Standards Operating Procedures Manual
hereto attached to Ordinance 3093-11 and made a part thereof shall be in full
legal force and effect.
(Ord. 3314-25. Passed 3-20-25.)
CHAPTER 141
Fire Department
141.01   Composition.
141.02   Powers and duties.
141.03   Driver operators.
141.04   Probationary period.
141.05   Officers.
141.06   Appointment.
141.07   Benefits.
141.08   Sick leave.
141.09   Physical examination.
141.10   Compensation for drills, calls and runs.
141.11   Expense reimbursement.
141.12   Release from active duty because of sickness or accident.
141.13   Volunteer Firemen’s Dependents Fund Board.
141.14   Practices and procedure manual.
141.15   Junior Firefighter’s Program.
141.16   Reserve Firefighter Program.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Volunteer Firemen’s Dependents Fund - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 146
Fire protection contracts - see Ohio R.C. 307.05, 505.44, 717.02
Schooling, buildings and equipment - see Ohio R.C. 715.05, 737.23 et seq.
Gas masks for firemen; requirements - see Ohio R.C. 3737.31
 
 
141.01 COMPOSITION.
   (a)   There is hereby established a Fire Department within the Village to be
known as "The McDonald Fire Fighter's Organization" and which shall consist of
the following:
      (1)   One (1) Chief;
      (2)   And not more than thirty-one (31) other members of the Department.
   (b)   And may consist of one or more of the following officers:
      (1)   One (1) Assistant Fire Chief;
      (2)   Two (2) Captains;
      (3)   Three (3) Lieutenants.
         (Ord. 3278-23. Passed 3-16-23.)
141.02 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The firemen shall have the following duties:
   (a)   The care, custody, maintenance and cleaning of the fire equipment and
the entire Municipal Building.
   (b)   The firemen shall provide for the care and feeding of prisoners at the
rate of no more than ten dollars ($10.00) per day.
   (c)   The firemen shall make all repairs at the Municipal Building,
equipment and machinery where tools and facilities will permit them to do so.
   (d)   The firemen shall be a resident of the Village for at least one year
prior to his appointment.
   (e)   The firemen shall be on duty an average of sixty hours per week.
   (f)   The firemen and firemen relief men shall come under the direct
supervision of the Mayor and he may set the schedule and weekly hours of
firemen.
   (g)   The full-time firemen shall be on duty from Monday 8:00 a.m. through
Saturday 8:00 a.m. unless relieved or excused from duty by the Mayor.
   (h)   The firemen shall operate the police radio, act as jailer for the
police department, and perform any other reasonable duties as may be required
by the Mayor. (Ord. 2575-91. Passed 4-3-91.)
141.03 DRIVER OPERATORS.
   (a)   There is hereby created the position of twelve driver operators,
formerly known as assistant firemen, appointed by the Mayor with the advice and
consent of Council. Their term of office shall be for one year.
   (b)   The driver operators shall be the relief men for the full-time
firemen, and when on duty in the absence of the full-time firemen, exercise the
same duties and have the same responsibilities as the firemen hereinbefore
mentioned.
   (c)   The Fire Chief shall schedule the driver operators to relieve or
replace the full-time firemen when such full-time firemen are off duty.
(Ord. 2575-91. Passed 4-3-91.)
141.04 PROBATIONARY PERIOD.
   (a)   The full-time firemen and driver operators shall serve a six-months
satisfactory probationary period upon receiving an original appointment.
   (b)   The probationary period, as set out in subsection (a) hereof, shall
not pertain to full- time firemen or driver operators, formerly known as
assistant firemen, who have satisfactorily served six months in such positions
prior to the effective date of this chapter.
(Ord. 2575-91. Passed 4-3-91.)
141.05 OFFICERS.
   (a)   There is hereby created up to seven (7) officers within the McDonald
Fire Fighter's Organization. The titles of these officers shall be a Fire
Chief, and may further consist of:
      (1)   One (1) Assistant Fire Chief;
      (2)   Two (2) Captains; and
      (3)   Three (3) Lieutenants.
   (b)   The duties of such officers designated in subsection (a) hereof shall
be those duties as are set forth in the Village Fire Fighter's manual or other
duties as the Fire Chief, Mayor or Council shall direct from time to time.
   (c)   The chain of command of the officers of the McDonald Fire Fighter's
Organization shall be according to the following sequence:
      First in command      Fire Chief
      Second in command      Assistant Fire Chief, if appointed
      Third in command       Captains, if appointed
      Fourth in command      Lieutenants, if appointed
   (d)   All officers shall be appointed from active members of the McDonald
Fire Fighter's Organization. (Ord. 3125-12. Passed 12-19-12.)
141.06 APPOINTMENT.
   Officers and members of the McDonald Fire Fighters Organization shall be
appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by Council in accordance with the McDonald
Fire Fighter’s manual. (Ord. 3125-12. Passed 12-19-12.)
141.07 BENEFITS.
   Full-time firemen shall receive all of the benefits currently received by
other Village officers and employees, such as, vacations, paid holidays as
designated by ordinance, hospitalization, etc., except sick leave, which is
hereafter set out in Section
141.08.
(Ord. 2575-91. Passed 4-3-91.)
141.08 SICK LEAVE.
   The sick leave of full-time firemen shall be accumulated at the rate of four
and six-tenths hours with pay for every eighty hours of service. The firemen
shall be charged for sick leave at the rate of equal hours of sick leave for
each duty hour he is absent from work and may accumulate 2160 hours of sick
leave. (Ord. 2575-91. Passed 4-3-91.)
141.09 PHYSICAL EXAMINATION.
   The full-time firemen shall, not more than sixty days prior to receiving
such appointment, as full-time firemen, pass a physical examination given by a
licensed physician showing that he meets the physical requirements necessary to
perform the duties of such position. The professional fee for such physical
examination shall be paid for by the Village.
(Ord. 2575-91. Passed 4-3-91.)
141.10 COMPENSATION FOR DRILLS, CALLS AND RUNS.
   (a)   The Fire Chief and Assistant Fire Chief shall be compensated for
ambulance runs in the amount of ten and 95/100 dollars ($10.95) per run in
addition to their salaries, as officers of the McDonald Fire Fighter’s
Organization.
(Ord. 3016-07. Passed 5-2-07.)
   (b)   The driver operators shall be compensated at the hourly rate as
established by Council for duties actually performed in relief of, or
substituting for, the full-time firemen. Driver operators shall be compensated
for drills, fire calls and ambulance runs when not on duty a driver operators
in relief of full-time firemen. (Ord. 2575-91. Passed 4-3-91.)
   (c)   Volunteer firemen shall be compensated as follows:
      (1)   Drills actually attended and participated in until conclusion:
         seven dollars and sixty-five cents ($7.65) per drill.
      (2)   Fire calls actually attended and duties performed under the
direction and until relieved by an officer of the department:
         ten dollars and ninety-five cents ($10.95) per fire call.
      (3)   Ambulance runs actually participated in and duties performed -
- Attendants (drivers) eight and 80/100 ($8.80) per run; EMT’s Nine and 05/100
dollars ($9.05) per run; Intermediate EMT’s Thirteen and 25/100 ($13.25) per
run; and Paramedic EMT’s Sixteen and 00/100 Dollars ($16.00) per run. (Ord.
3016-07. Passed 5-2-07.)
141.11 EXPENSE REIMBURSEMENT.
   All members of the McDonald Fire Fighters Organization may be reimbursed for
expenses when attending training sessions, seminars, schooling, classes, etc.,
when such education or training is directly pertaining to the betterment and
efficiency of their performance as firefighters or ambulance attendants, where
approved in advance by the Mayor.
(Ord. 2575-91. Passed 4-3-91.)
141.12 RELEASE FROM ACTIVE DUTY BECAUSE OF SICKNESS OR ACCIDENT.
   (a)   The Mayor and the Chief of the Fire Department are hereby authorized
to excuse from duty, without deduction in pay, any regular member of the Fire
Department because of sickness or accident contracted in the ordinary course of
events or for injury or sickness arising within the scope of his duty. (1940
Code Sec. 365)
   (b)   The Mayor and the Chief of the Fire Department may require proof of
sickness, accident or disability by physical examination on the part of any
physician whom they may choose or the Mayor and the Chief of the Fire
Department may accept the certificate of a regular practicing physician. (1940
Code Sec. 368)
141.13 VOLUNTEER FIREMEN’S DEPENDENTS FUND BOARD.
   A volunteer Firemen’s Dependents Fund Board is hereby established to be
constituted and have such powers and duties as provided under Ohio R.C. Chapter
146.
(Ord. 2030-74. Passed 5-21-74.)
141.14 PRACTICES AND PROCEDURE MANUAL.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Pursuant to Ordinance 2985-06, passed March 15, 2006 the
Village has adopted a Manual of Practical Procedure for the McDonald Volunteer
Fire Department. Copies are on file at the Village Hall.)
141.15 JUNIOR FIREFIGHTER’S PROGRAM.
   (a)   There is hereby established a Junior Firefighter’s Program within the
Fire Department of the Village of McDonald.
   (b)   Applicants shall be between the ages of sixteen but not yet eighteen
years of age and a resident of the Village at the time the application for the
appointment is made to the Fire Department.
   (c)   The applicants for the Junior Firefighter’s Program shall be appointed
by the Mayor and confirmed by Council.
   (d)   The Junior Firefighter’s Program shall be governed in accordance with
the rules and regulations as established by the Practices and Procedure Manual
of the McDonald Fire Department.
   (e)   The Village shall pay each Junior Firefighter biannually a sum
sufficient to pay for the Firefighter’s insurance as provided by the State
Firefighter’s Association.
(Ord. 2266-81. Passed 3-17-81.)
141.16 RESERVE FIREFIGHTER PROGRAM.
   (a)   There is hereby established a Reserve Firefighter Program within the
Village of McDonald Fire Department.
   (b)   Applicants for the Reserve Firefighter Program must be at least
eighteen years of age; must have graduated high school or obtained a GED; and
must be attending a college or trade school full time, which full time status
shall be determined by the educational institution.
   (c)   Reserve Firefighters shall be on a provisional status until they are
eligible to become permanent volunteers of the Village of McDonald Fire
Department. The provisional status shall not exceed four years without a
mayoral extension.
   (d)   The Reserve Firefighter Program shall be governed in accordance with
further Rules and Regulations as established by the Village Fire Department.
(Ord. 3045-08. Passed 11-5-08.)
CHAPTER 143
Village Administrator
143.01   Established; appointment.
143.02   Powers and duties.
 
CROSS REFERENCES

143.01 ESTABLISHED; APPOINTMENT.
   There is hereby established the position of Village Administrator who shall
be appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by Council.
(Ord. 2250-80. Passed 12-30-80.)
143.02 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (a)   The Village Administrator shall have such authority as provided by law
and the ordinances and resolutions of this Village not inconsistent herewith.
Such authority, duties, and responsibilities shall be as follows:
      (1)   To manage, conduct and control the Water Department, Street
Department and sanitary treatment plant of the Village including all water and
sewer lines, collection and distribution facilities, buildings and storage
facilities, vehicles, equipment and all other material, tools or appurtenances
incidental to the operation of the Water, Sewer and Street departments of the
Village.
      (2)   To collect or provide for the collection of all water rents and
sewer charges.
      (3)   To supervise the improvement and repair of all streets, avenues,
alleys, lands, lanes, squares, landings, market houses, bridges, viaducts,
sidewalks, sewers, drains, ditches, culverts, channels, streams and
watercourses as well as the lighting, sprinkling, and cleaning of all streets,
alleys and public buildings and places within the Village.
      (4)   To attend any meeting requested by the Mayor.
      (5)   To supervise the maintenance and repair of all public buildings,
parks, playgrounds and other recreational facilities.
      (6)   To function as the purchasing agent for the Street, Water,
Wastewater and Parks and Recreation Departments in the Village in order to
secure benefits derived from buying in quantity.
      (7)   The Village Administrator shall be responsible for administering
the budgetary and fiscal plan provided annually by Council for the Water, Sewer
and Street Departments.
   (b)    The Village Administrator shall be under the general supervision and
control of the Mayor and shall have such other powers and duties as are
prescribed by ordinance or by law and which are not inconsistent herewith.
   (c)   The Village Administrator shall perform all duties and shall have all
powers of the former Board of Public Affairs and the Street Commissioner as
prescribed by law except as otherwise provided herein. (Ord. 2250-80. Passed
12-30-80; Adopting Ordinance.)
